orB2bRS2KcPu2mTDdKXc6w.text: I haven't had the best of times with The Book Club. I tried to book it for my website's birthday. I tried a month in advance. Spoke to three different people. Not one of them got back to me. If you're looking to book out an area for an event, I'd go elsewhere. And because of that, I didn't come here as quickly as I would have, I was just totally unconvinced by their service. So I came, I saw and I liked. I'm still not convinced by the place. Don't get me wrong, great venue, cool ping pong tables. Nice enough staff. But a £10 minimum is always going to piss me off (especially when I'm not told in advance despite holding a card). I don't like the high minimum spends. We're not in the dark ages and it basically stops people drinking on their own. I wasn't, but I did have to wait until my date arrived before I bought a drink. The wine was alright, I wasn't fussed. I don't actually get what all the fuss is about. I'm sure if you come here for an event it's fun. The place is nice (and would be nicer if they tidied up a bit and cleared some tables). Thing is, I won't recommend them to anyone for an event, and I'd already decided that I'd dock a star because of their incompetence earlier in the year. It's left a really bad taste in my mouth and the bar just isn't awesome enough for me to forget it.

_bPKRGtLQ2HWqcTaCFZ9XQ.text: Went here for a breakfast meeting with one of them trendy Shoreditch media types... definitely the place for it. They've got a regular menu of events from poetry and philosophy to music and networking. It also appears to be quite a decent bar. Obviously it's less easy to judge that in the cold light of day...Neat little brunch menu, the scrambled eggs were particularly fine!

fjDBi3wjr-ubPdowt68XCg.text: Came here for my birthday in November as it was the only place in London that didnt have a crazy queue at the door. Entry was £10 each to get in, which, considering the size of the place, was ridiculous.There are two floors, each with a bar. Drinks were reasonably priced, but the queues for the bar were so long and chaotic, we didnt bother at times.The downstairs area is the main dance area. Its quite small, which is fine, but theres a pool table in the middle of nowhere so it can get annoying and crowded if a group decide to play.The bouncers can be quite rude, with one particular scary looking woman screaming at you to get out the way, or to show your stamp everytime you want to go upstairs/downstairs.Three stars because drinks were ok, and the djs were really enthusiastic.

RhlVC4Bei03VuZH_Eoayfw.text: Not the lowest prices but not outrageous. Fan of the potato wedges and Ham & Eggs always goes down well at lunch. Laid back during the day, sometimes gets too busy though.

mZdkNEeCr9jutvDG_zGEyw.text: We stumbled upon this place after walking around Shoreditch in search of a pho joint. Though most places were closed, the Book Club beckoned with it's ping pong table, kitschy decor, and the promise of food.  There's also a pool table downstairs and a space for shows.The ambiance was good, with a relaxed vibe, and the service was pretty good -- fast and friendly enough.  In the tradition of English pubs, food and drink orders are placed at the bar, where you pay on the spot.  We ordered a couple of beers, the roast dinner (can't remember what meat), veggie full English breakfast, and a side of pork scratchings.     The pork scratchings were alright, but nothing to write home about.  They tasted like they were straight from a bag, but still...they were crunchy and salty enough to satisfy my junk food craving.  And, I'm partial to crackling. Loved the veggie full English breakfast. The soy based sausages reminded me a bit of those from Rosamunde in SF, but a little tastier, and the hashbrowns were perfect, crispy golden chunks of goodness.  According to my other half, the same couldn't be said about the roast dinner; the meat wasn't moist and the flavor wasn't as good as a typical roast.  In all, still a pretty solid-ish place.  I'm giving this a four because...well, because of the ping pong. Who doesn't like a game after a few beers?I'd definitely go back to try other things on their menu.  Even if not for the food, I'd hit up Book Club again for a cold beer,  some ping pong/ pool action, or catch a show.

8rC1fZa83i8AnMpt2hr0KQ.text: My friends and I came here for brunch on a Sunday.  Casual atmosphere with communal tables, and I love how there's enough space between tables so you don't feel cramped.  It's spacious, yet has a ping pong table in the back and a billiards table downstairs.I also love the exposed brick walls with horizontal oval cutouts, and the large windows.  Very laid back and seems like a great place to hang out and waste a few hours.The food was fine, nothing spectacular (but maybe I'm just used to the really creative brunch fare in New York) but decent, and reasonably priced.

Im6gscy6LqU8K6x2W5WVbQ.text: I love this place, It has an unforgettable charm that is difficult to get past to. they open all day and serve coffees and beers ( a great plus for someone that can drink coffee at the latest minute ) The star of the place is the ping pong table, free to play if you can seize on the table before anyone else (not so difficult) The decor is great with daring mixed furniture. The food is also surprisingly good with awesome international sharing platters at reasonable prices. Lovely stuff for all the Shoreditch types

3vTMaAzuKhv-OWzNu50v6g.text: It's good to know it!!Lee KunTravel News (travelblog.friendlybooki…)  Dat Phong Khach San (luxurybooking.net)

BsPn_pluGV9Z4BfRjTQYDQ.text: I've had a couple nights here and they've both been excellent. Both times the bar/restaurant/club mashup has had a great atmosphere. The first was on one of their "Thinking and Drinking" nights where for a fiver I got to have a play with a robot hand as well as a glass of wine. The second was a Friday night out (free entry before 9) and had a great time. Upstairs the table tennis keeps on going while downstairs there's a pool table, as well as a DJ and dance floor. Very cool - over the dance floor the ceiling is made of light bulbs - I don't think picking up a mate on the dance floor is a good idea. It's the kind of place that you can go early and stay through to the early hours without ever feeling out of place. Had a wicked time and looking forward to my next visit.

FugaCScBwdudu8RYf1Uqxw.text: One of the great things about Shoreditch is that there are tonnes of great places for one to hang out, whether it's day or night. And the only thing similar about each of these venues is that they all offer something different. I suspect I might not be explaining myself all that well, but if you're a regular in this part of town, I hope you get what I mean. T.B.C., I'm happy to say, is the same as the other clubs in the area in its different-ness. What other place here - or in London - has a room dedicated to table tennis? From what I can tell, this room is in use regularly, although it's safe to say I won't be partaking in this. For one thing, my grip is very loose when I'm sober, so there's no telling who'll get hurt if I'm even slightly intoxicated, and, more importantly, I'm ethnic Chinese, so I'd be risking the reputation of my forefathers if I end up losing, never mind that I've never actually played before. T.B.C. has two areas: the upstairs dining area where the table tennis is, and the downstairs DJ and dance area, where you'll find a room with a shelf full of books (hence, the name). I didn't get a close look at the books, but I did see some people returning some tomes, which, in my opinion, makes this place that much cooler. I love places which provide books for you to while away the time. It just feels so welcoming and relaxing. There's also a pool table here in case you haven't yet found something to keep you busy. The furniture here seems cobbled together in that it's almost artistically mismatched. I'm not sure if it worked too well in the dining area; from where I was sitting (a comfy sofa located by the entrance so I'd get hit by blasts of cold air every time someone entered), some of the seats - or rather benches - looked rather uncomfortable. In contrast, the basement gave off an Ikea-cafe- meets-speakeasy feel. The ceiling of the bar in the basement was essentially a net full of light bulbs, which made me very nervous as a couple of them looked as if they might fall. There're quite a few events going on at this venue, and it's safe to say I'll definitely be back to check them out some time in the near future. Just as a last note, T.B.C. is owned by the same people who own The Queen of Hoxton, which is another really cool Shoreditch hang-out, so it's safe to say these guys have some experience of knowing what makes a club a great place to be.

zKtphA9cuO9-AYcyE0qAzQ.text: Nice place, it deserves 5 stars just for having something called the Shoreditch twat on the drhinks menu! The atmosphere is great, good music, 1960s decoration and lots of comfy seats on the ground floor...must check this out outside night hours, with its free wi-fi, sofas and breakfast menu seems a good place to bring a book and read (or to just look intellectual pretending it). Have a look at their website, lots of events coming up every week.

gFEBK_VgBYkVtIbVOj3tTA.text: Had a brilliant chilled out Sunday afternoon at TBC, the decor is fantastic, I was so obsessed with the oval window on the wall that I had to take a picture of it. The artwork is also very interesting and thought provoking.As we only stayed for an hour or so my friend and I only had a quick drink and some chips: they were the best chips I've ever had, very chunky and sprinkled with freshly ground pepper and salt.The service is so friendly, one of the TBC staff said she loves working there and she was always smiling (hard to come by as so many people hate their jobs nowadays).I will definitely be back for the cultural events, the life drawing workshops look interesting indeed.

uw2daW3Biqn0o4pPh38j7A.text: Really enjoyed the vibe and trendy artwork. Great place to sit with your laptop or have a game of table tennis! Very spacious too

ZTjFnsvlaSAGRVW3qufOsw.text: A "Jolly Roger" cocktail served in a ceramic mug, tasting of pure alchomaholic joy (I love candy).I dig the atmosphere, very very much actually. Wooden benches, tables, chairs, good lighting, and ping pong. Haven't tried the food, but will definitely return for drinks and atmosphere.

r1OQ2w4kfOrw2yx6nlR2Aw.text: 5 stars for the setup of the place, ambience, and service. Had the salmon/cod cake with watercress. It was good.

OMAtjVLsSCuG-dcTCnq47Q.text: Love this place. The cocktails are great, the layout is open and original with two floors of fun plus a ping pong table, and they have loads of interesting nights. Perfect place for a fun night out with friends. Like them on facebook to keep up with everything that goes on there. If you're good at table tennis you could win bar tab

ilB20f5A13a87Qe4KdFd1g.text: I came here on a sunday evening when it was mostly empty, and hosing a craft market downstairs. I had the best food that I have eaten out in a long time, enjoyed a fun game of table tennis and pool and chilled out in their incredibly low sofas. I will definitely be going back!

8Bgc1tkpalZuP9-IavvWdA.text: Had previously been to Home Bar in this spot where an overzealous bouncer had proceeded not to let us back in after popping out for cash/food despite having been in the place all afternoon. We hadn't got our hands stamped you see, even though he hadn't offered when we left.Anyhow, I can't hold this new place responsible (although the bouncer did look familiar..) when I went for the opening night the place was full of very drunk people and the atmosphere was one of ramshackle cool. I must go back for one of their very interesting looking events, which tend to have a literary bent as you might guess from the name, or for an afternoon game of ping pong.

_Qjs-jxO8MWbH_3gTSk4dQ.text: I'm with Siany on this one - Book Club is the kind of place you either love or hate. I came here on a Saturday night for my friend's birthday and he had booked a table in the centre of the ground floor. Arriving fairly early the atmosphere was good, slight queues at the bar but good music. In a way it deteriorated as the night went on, 20-minute wait to get a drink, toilets were dirty (and I'm honestly not a fan of the unisex loo option) music getting lounder and more random (s-express got my attention but there were some very dodgy moments as well)Cocktails were from £6.95 - £8.00ish, which is fairly cheap for this area. Liked the decor, tiled walls, quite open-plan, a thumping dark dancefloor downstairs whith different music and a ping-pong table in the rear.I've actually heard it's a lovely place to come in the daytime for brunch etc so that sounds more like my scene. Plus under-25 'hipsters' that are painfully image-aware freak me out when I'm out of an evening.

1mD4qlVodsNQKR_mBNjXuA.text: Fun club and good restaurant during the day with free wifi.  Yes it's in the middle of Shoreditch so it's a fair amount of hipsters, but it draws a friendly crowd and they have lots of fun themes (Life drawing + drinking, DIY Bloody Marys..).  The cocktails are expensive and the line can be long so get there early-ish and pregame.  But the music is great and it's worth it.

e-x6DDXvYqYEhhwLUFHJJg.text: SPACE. There is so much delicious space here. I met a friend for coffee and we found it oh so difficult to get up afterwards. There is a wonderful amount of breathing space in the book club and the atmosphere that goes with it encourages your return.Picture yourself all stuffed up in your flat and screaming at a screen... no space, no coffee. Then move that screen into a lovely large open space, with mix-matched chairs, big mugs of coffee, others with screens and bright open windows. Doesn't that sound like something you would want regularly?To top it off, they seem to some really snazzy events on after dark. The broad opening hours fit it all in.I will regulate this place.Awesome.

9Z0xuCa2PhETDjrIKm0NTw.text: Nice place for breakfast and working away on your computer (free wifi of course). actually it served us as kind of an office for more than a month. including breaks at the ping pong table.it gets a bit smelly and smokey after lunch though. the downside of an open kitchen.

bmKSsVPJrUQs4ii0YWMAGA.text: Great food, reasonably priced. Really cool place to come with your laptop and get some work done or just to eat/drink with friends. Quite a few people here even at 3pm on a weekday afternoon. The chips, in particular, are definitely worth trying!

photos.caption: Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom

SCCyp71QzJrql-hdq32IQg.text: Loud music (even during the day, i.e. where you can't be heard ordering your tea) and iffy teapots (all metal so they cool down too quickly) and a little on the spendy side.On the up side, they've great events and good community and lovely deco and nice cakes and teas and beers and foods.All round good. I'd probably give it 3 1/2 stars in all actuality but they've go the je ne sais quois to go one better.

IFtrDAPViXsjfb3DbzomkA.text: Take me on a date here.  The vast amount of natural light pouring through the huge windows make me look super hot.From afternoon tea and some wifi neccessary work to introducing out-of-town guests to the polite and "accessible" side of Shoreditch, this is the place to go.The Book Club has great music, a full bar, and an extensive snack and dinner menu.  The veggie platter is fresh and the cajun potatoes wedges with sour cream and sweet/sour sauce are perfect to share over a dark and stormy.  They also have an extensive events calendar, which you can pick up at the door in a super fun fold-out format (sometimes paper is better than online).  Hint Hint, there are plenty of opportunities for you ask me to an event to see how super hot I look.The staff is fairly friendly, whilst reminding you that they were hired not the serve, but look cool.FYI: No card transactions less than £10, so pick up some cash en route.

0dGTEJ0Z88h4gyCWdFLOfw.text: Food was good but nothing life-changing. Staff ignored me pretty much the whole time but were friendly enough once approached.

jL_6csyrJE19ugLLE2fNZA.text: Had brunch here this weekend -  I would give the place 5 stars for comfort (love the couches by the window) and relaxed atmosphere (had my little puppy with me and they didnt mind me bringing her in).The food was just OK - the full english was decent but nothing special.  At £8.5 was a little pricey for the quality.Just FYI - you have to go up to the counter and order for yourself - we didnt realize this and ended up waiting at the table for a while.

DqpNXRpuaopADxtaNbdR9w.text: Been here a couple of times now. Once on a night out and once for drinks mid week. Night out was very busy downstairs, perhaps too busy in a way but they were playing good music. It's cool how they have the table tennis upstairs. For drinks, I got some nachos and they were very tasty, approx £6. They always have some good stuff going on downstairs mid week too, check out their website for links to Facebook events.  Would recommend.

AG8Z60ILl-syxxxeGZZ1sQ.text: Just one gear on my fixie bike, I've got a plus one here for my gig tonight.Oh, sorry, what? Oh, I'm writing a review .. right. The Book Club somewhat suffers (well, actually, benefits) from being smack-bang in the middle of that swathe of East London that has been colonised by the Hipster. There's no doubting that this place is firm hipster territory, there's a lot of them here but it doesn't mean you have to be a hipster to enjoy it. I came for lunch here with my friend on a weekday afternoon and we managed to get a decent window seat with no wait. The décor is very nice, wooden furniture, exposed brick walls, there's big black and white prints up all around and the large windows ensure it's nice and light. The menu is pretty solid, I had ham, egg and chips. Sorry, I mean I had hand-cured honey ham, free-range egg and home-made crispy chipped potatoes. And my friend had vegetarian lasagne which was, actually, advertised as just "vegetarian lasagne" in their credit. Ours both came in around the £7-8 mark for a main meal and it arrived really quickly, literally about 10 minutes after we ordered. I have to say it was really good, solid food. The chips were amazing, properly crispy, the egg was cooked perfectly and the ham was in big slabs and they weren't short on portions either.I can't say anything about the drinks as we had tap water from the iced jugs on the bar (extra kudos for that) and neither can I say anything about this place in the evening. There's a ping-pong table at the back near the toilets which I gather is home to a tournament and there were paddles and balls out so we could have played if we'd wanted to. I loved the way the seating was arranged with tables and communal benches but plenty of room to move around so you're not smacking people in the face with your uber-trendy canvas bags when you're trying to leave. I also thought the staff were quite friendly for a hipster-orientated establishment. All in all I'll give this place 4 stars based on this one visit. I think we might have been lucky or maybe it's always this good. It's somewhere I want to take people in the future and be all "oh yeah, I heard about this place from a friend" about.

4SSD7y7dgHPWzUzSUqHHRg.text: I ended up here at about 7 on a Friday night. It was the perfect spot to start our night. First thing...I was impressed that to gain entrance we didn't have to pay but to offer up an email address. Slightly annoying but a damn good idea from a marketing perspective. Upon entering the space we were greeted with a perfectly lit room filled with young, (mostly) attractive professionals engaging in spirited conversation. We ordered at the bar which is where you also order food. I partook in a shot special and a few beers. Played some table tennis, chatted with my friends and generally had a great time. The bars in london in many cases are very fashionable, as was Book Club. But it also had something else that made it comfortable and warranted a fifth star. Bonus for the nice bathrooms.Great place. Check it out.

HnqhC_l-wVfXpe8qYl-Asw.text: TBC has amazing breakfast and the atmosphere is great. The staff is very friendly and can strongly recommend the place for a relaxing morning.

6j13bYc9d3usr1ZJe1H6qA.text: I'd missed a few events at the book club, but I finally got around to attending for Halloween. The highlights: friendly bartenders who knew what they were doing, very easy to get to/from, an interesting space for a bar. Cons: there isn't very much seating, and as we were with a group of 11 it took a while before everyone had a chair. Additionally, it was unclear as to how ordering food was meant to take place. All in all, I would go again but maybe during the daytime.

XHRjC_ylFZZY32TO3BKL_g.text: I've been to this place 3 days in a row now and I always look forward to the next meal here. So far, I've had the Full English Breakfast, the chicken, and the halibut dishes. They were all very good.The ingredients are fresh, the atmosphere is hip, and the service is great!I upped my rating by one star because I think it's THAT good.

kOnqsbFiNH7a_UJF_IqKBw.text: Like a lady on the street but a freak in the bed, The Book Club services all my needs. Yeah yeah yeah. Went to the Club with my homie, tryna get a lil cocktails, keep it down on the low key. Crowd was heavy, it had me feelin' like whoa...Cocktails were fresh, I got so caught up, I was screaming Yeah, yeah, yeah She asked for ping pong, I said come and get me In the club lookin' so conspicuous. She asked for one more game, it ain't over till we play doubles. Take that and rewind it back, time for brunch So we decided to chill How you like me now, veggie full English and a crowd so cool Now I gotta keep it real now, staff so a certified twenty They bring the food and I'mLike yeah, how the hell am I supposed to leave? Yeah yeah yeah

vJJhqQESaL-ob5ESxGj_aA.text: I wanted to review the Literary Death Match, but can't work out how to. Instead, it's location gets a shout out!Our friend Olly has been going about the Literary Death Match for months. Cast your mind back to 8 Mile, with Eminem chickening out the first time he has to battle that super-confident rapper with dreads. Remember? Well, it's that like (the founder is from Brooklyn after all) - but with prose, comedy and poetry. Though it's been held in London before. Last Wednesday's event was for the first time held at The Book Club in Shoreditch - which in itself was lovely. A two-floored hideaway with a neon-lit bar up top (we had food afterwards, a hot & cold meze platter big enough for three costs £12 and we bulked it up with some extra wedges). Anyway, nice nibbles aside, the basement was the location for the 'match'.We arrived and I was distracted by the lightbulb ceiling (made entirely from lightbulbs pinned to the wooden beams) for a good ten minutes. 150 people ended up crushing in, and off we went.Round 1. Two contestants with seven minutes each to read any type of literature. Both are then judged by the panel of three (last night, it was singer/artist Molly Carroll tasked on 'intangibles', tv presenter/actress Emma Kennedy on performance and Rising Magazine's Tim Wells on form).  A winner is then announced, and then after round two - a final. This time around, it consisted on throwing Cadbury Crème Eggs through holes cut out of British authors faces. Bizarre. I would have liked to have seen some kind of improvisation instead.Anyway, it was bloody good fun and I'll definitely go again. Seven minutes seems to be the perfect length of time to hold a room's attention and it's a really unique type of event to go to.The LDM's are held all around the world, so check literarydeathmatch.com for more details.

c0wdtqGjcAqso3HdAQR-Ew.text: This place needs yelp. It's crying out for people to know about it! With a huge space, regular talks and lectures as well as a ping pong table, The Book Club deserves to survive.I came here for tea and cake over the weekend and was impressed with a tasty apple tart and super friendly Shoreditch Twats serving me. There were a few couples snuggled in corners brunching and a large group of people in the middle all around one table having breakfast. Even though there were people there the place just seemed empty, apparently it's always like this during the day so potentially a great place to get some solid reading done or get on with work.Thomas W is fair with his 3 stars but i think I would make this spot a regular haunt, so i'm going to throw 4 at it.

roGr3z3R635XnioAYmuHJQ.text: The Book Club - i am really really looking forward to going back to this place tonight. I, by definition, am not a Shoreditch person. I do not like wearing things that clutch to my skin, my sun glasses fit my face, and i do not have Top Shop/man buyers stalking me on the street trying to get an idea of what the next seasons, scene fashion fix will be! I never thought i would feel so at home at the Book Club, but then again, how can you not? The furniture is charming, comfy and different! It really compliments the relaxing and opposingly lively environment that the Book Club creates.The last time i was there, i took a date. I was very cautious about this at first, as well, i did not know what to expect - and well i wanted to impress the girl! Whatever initial scepticism i had  vanished as soon as we went downstairs to shoot a couple of rounds of pool (great for flirtation!) But my god, what is wrong with London?! This is possibly the only bar i have been to in the whole of London that has a pool table! What the hell is that all about? I am a Northerner for gods sake, it has come to be an expectation of going out for a drink!Now after a bit of pool, we headed upstairs to have a few more drinks. The music is pretty standard for the area, but for London as a whole is pretty good! I do not remember hearing anything particularly rare, but it was certainly all tasteful. Heading upstairs, we had a few rounds of table tennis with an American couple (who we destroyed) Where else in London can you play table tennis? This bar is legendary for this reason alone!The bar also has a really large underground space and while we were there was some kind of hip hop gig on. The acoustics were great and while it was quite loud, you could quite happily escape the noise and cosy up on a sofa next door to talk. Great night, lovely service, nice people, table tennis.

FYNhiBdl13dbBsm8jEdEJg.text: a really comfortable space to enjoy a few drinks and foods. it is spacious, good for a group of people.

KVgdyuf3vd1Wie2mnkfRtA.text: This is a pretty cool place and spacious, however I wasn't too impressed with the £7 charge to get in and the £10 minimum spend on cards. Also, the lager my other half had was very flat and tasted nasty. I think I'd much prefer this place earlier in the evening and perhaps on a weeknight with friends rather than on a crowded Saturday night.

W6WTAk3D9o6r5X41CRBKmQ.text: Book club has a lot of potential but strikes out in many places. I've been for lunch and the food was plain and boring. I've been for a couple nights out and there is a cover, endless queue for the bar, and the downstairs, while playing good music, gets overly hot and stinky (and I can usually handle hot and stinky but this was over the top). I wouldn't waste your time unless you come here for the beginning of the night out to get a few drinks and a little jig before moving on.

rPGLMLCqICmnPWrzG8DTag.text: This place has a fantastic programme of events--live art, salons, etc--along with great food and pretty good drinks and ping pong tables. Just an overall exciting mix of things to do and see.Minus a star for the difficult layout downstairs--half the room just can't see what's going on "onstage" no matter where they put the stage for the evening.

OwBVquMhn7Lj6rMCNbdRKg.text: I really do like this place. Not just for its great location but it has many cool events for all different kinds of people. It also has one of my favourite past times which is a free ping pong table! Result!

ctM07MDQ6VEc2pJ6QvtlBA.text: We went on a Thursday night for some ping pong and drinks. The upstairs is more casual while the downstairs seemed to be rocking loud music and a different crowd. Ping pong is free with a deposit that they return when you give the balls/paddles back.

01-ApUShb7daVCjTeHB1nQ.text: I only know this place as a place to drink and dance. If that's what you're after then I don't think this is the place for you. The bar is a nightmare for getting served once the place gets busy, the hip bar staff seem to be too cool to give you the time of day whilst serving you. The crowd is of course dependant on the night, that too has been a mixed back. You're looking at people on their early 20's and students. The club part downstairs is fine too but they let in too many people in the place so it gets uncomfortable on occasion, oh and did I mention if you want a drink you'll have to queue up for about an hour post 9pm? Tread carefully.

I8U3Xi49FdSrsJgFWIPcmA.text: 5 stars for the venue and the ambiance. But the food was terrible; and the service lacking.

bQSUHZhvZuDkq8CwyIWw0g.text: I'm not a fan. The Book Club has fallen into the trap of bars in Shoreditch (McQueen's being another) that will turn away people on the basis of their not being a mixed group. It is an absolute nonsense.When we did finally make it through the hallowed entrance, I came to realise that the bar falls into the trap of many licenced restaurants - invariably the quality of the beer suffers. They are by-the-numbers lagers, with poorly serviced lines, meaning the lager is tasteless and flat.Given the other reviews, this may have been a bad day. Unfortunately, I will not be going back any time soon to check.

rKKJuyP46MO-kEKjV7Ei3Q.text: Had a lovely evening here at a Screen Social event. It involved a dj, a bar, some short films playing on several walls around the downstairs events area and it's social, so you can catch up with friends along the way! I can't wait to go back and try the food upstairs and my hand at some ping pong! It seems they have lots of great events downstairs so I'm extremely happy to have stumbled this treasure trove of interestingness in London and will report more once I've explored further!c*

L8kzIaBhDFy1LPwCq3f5zg.text: While waiting in the queue on Halloween night, I was told I would be unable to gain entry to the club based on an open can that I had in my hand. Fine, I thought, we'll go somewhere else. Two of my friends, frustrated with this situation, calmly began to ask the manager why this was the case. Immediately, two bouncers came up and started to ask my friends, "What are you going to do about it, you f*!?ing p-words?" They then began to scream at my friends, calling them the c-word multiple times. All this occurred as their manager stood there, CONDONING the behavior. When questioned as to why she would allow her employees to act in such an atrociously vulgar manner, she looked me in the eye and said "What are you going to achieve by questioning this?" I cannot believe that this venue is allowed to get away with this. I see a reviewer bellow making similar complaints. Please do not go somewhere that allows this behavior, it is truly disgusting.

7Y7ia-ZSWujfY_-pp4oomw.text: I love this place. It's a cafe-cum-lounge-cum-hipster hangout supreme. Or whatever.By day a great place to meet for lunch or coffee, with interesting, unique and healthy items on the menu. Quirky atmosphere.I loved this place even more when I went by night! In the downstairs bit, I danced my face off. Some awesome 60's & 70's music, a disco ball, a foosball table & old movies playing on a projector! How cold you not have a good time? I just started working & playing in Shoreditch a few months ago - so I expect many more visits to the book club in my future :)

1b2oc1khjjRLbws5SslgBQ.text: CANNOT wait to go back!! So fun. I liked it the minute I entered. This place is the perfect mix of a casual stop-in for a bite, a comfortable lounging area to do some reading and a hip bar (how do they do it?!?) - had brunch my first time but will be back for other reasons as well. My first full british breakfast was GREAT! I mean, was I that hungry or they just make beans so well?! (seriously, best beans I've had and that's gotta be the easiest thing to make.) And I tried two of the cocktails from their very long and intriguing cocktail list: something with chocolate and something with pear in the description - both excellent (pear one sweeter). I'll need to work myself through the list. Based on first experience - awesome place!

lIQoSr3jvlqn9D8OTVfU0A.text: Really quirky interesting place to study, private chat or hear some poetry. Their tea selection could be better. Overall good customer service.

tGg7i92Q6rrvaOg7Zo1NUQ.text: I've only ever been to the Book Club on a Sunday morning or afternoon. During these magic hours, the Book Club is less hipster hangout and more local cafe-cum-bar. Downbeat and unpretentious, you can drink London Fields on tap, eat some reasonably enjoyable food, listen to indie music from the early noughties, play some ping pong and tap in to the free wifi, all while relaxing in the spacious, light-filled ground floor.What more could you want? That being said, I wouldn't be caught dead coming here for an evening.

5iEKItIM3LArXUbxhZXuVA.text: If you're a hipster and are only thinking of coming here for drinks at night this review isn't for you. This place perplexes me. They supposedly open at 8am but more often than not I'm not able to order food at 8:30 or 8:45 because the chef hasn't shown up yet. This morning I walked up to place an order and the server asked me what I'd like and I ordered some food and she said the kitchen wasn't open yet, so I ordered some coffee and she said the coffee machine has been broken for a few days. After confirming that there was actually nothing I could order unless I wanted a cocktail at 8:30 in the morning I left.  You order food from the bar but there are no signs to that effect and the staff do not bother to mention it so I've made somewhat of a sport of watching people come in, sit down and look increasingly frustrated and confused until they either get up and walk out, or walk up to the bar and ask for a server at which point they are informed that they should be ordering at the bar and stared at incredulously by the staff as if they should have known that. Even when the place is nearly empty it can take 10 minutes to get a cup of coffee and it is delivered to the table with an air of extreme inconvenience.  If the food wasn't so good (when you can get it) and the wifi free I'd find somewhere else to eat breakfast.

uMkH2hfCR4_p6hRzDlgspg.text: The book club has become a bit of a regular haunt for me on the weekends. Good gins, local beers, friendly staff, a pool table....a ping pong table. It's cool!!! I liiiiiiike.

Ry7IEaX8fexN4rlgqyXXsA.text: I've visited the Book Club a few times, though never at night when the party probably gets started.  But, swinging by for a glass of wine after work while I read, this seemed like a pretty great place.  The bartenders are friendly, attentive, and adorable. They serve quickly and don't mind helping you if decision-making is a skill you were born without.  Free wifi is always a bonus, as is a creative approach to interior design.  While it may seem a bit odd, my favourite part of The Book Club is that it isn't crammed full of tables - you actually have room to yourself; a rarity in this city.

FI21JkVHNXNdwXeCSDoaiA.text: A taste of the Mission in the heart of London! Tabletennis table, Shoreditch hipsters in checked shirts and skinny jeans, 100% Mac users. I felt so at home, at home!Food was nothing special, but the atmosphere was quirky and cool. A great place to work on your start-up idea.

ERAoHT57gzGJapYyX2LXMQ.text: This used to be Home and is now a showroom for Ercol furniture and a place to play ironic table tennis.  On a Sunday afternoon to get drunk on it was underfilled and a bit cold.  The drinks were good and some of the alternative cabaret stuff might be interesting.  This might be one to reserve judgment on.Price - £standard hoxton

photos.caption: Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom. Just a selection of the Ercol furniture on offer to sit on

NNtRtqKkWPcRY9-rGi8HzQ.text: Without the comfy chairs and sofas near the windows I'm not sure this place would be all that. Still, it's nice to curl up every so often.

bsHWhZv5eUhVO-AP5kAHiQ.text: Fulll review and photos at thehappinessprojectlondo…  I shuddered slightly on my way into The Book Club in Shoreditch (just across the road from the Great Eastern Dining Room), because it used to be home to Home  one of the wankiest restaurants I've ever been to in London. I may have judged it a little harshly as it was my first meal in London after moving from Brussels where restos served great food on the cheap. I couldn't believe how much we paid for crap service and mediocre food, but then again I was spoiled Anyway, its now The Book Club, run by the same guys who do the Queen of Hoxton, and with a much nicer, friendlier atmosphere and a lovely bright and airy venue. The kind of place you can order a bottle of wine and Monopoly and chill out. The real gem of this place was the ping pong room. Yes, not just a table, a room. We went there on Tuesday night for Pippalippa's birthday when they hold a ping pong league there. You can just rock up and play, but by the personalised bats and serious faces, the league isn't really for tipsy amateurs like ourselves. Once the league games were over (about 9pm ish), filled with wine and sharing plates of fajitas and nachos, we managed to get on the tables. Pipalippa and I have something else in common  a previous history of taking ping pong very seriously. Aged 10-ish, I was enrolled on a week-long ping pong course in the Summer holidays (I have to thank my mother for imaginative yet random school holiday ideas), which meant I'm actually pretty shit-hot at smashes, backhand lunges and similar. Although I now realise that my 10-year-old sober self can probably play a lot better than my 30-something self after a few glasses of vino, oops. The photo below is typical of our games  which were mostly spent rescuing the ball from the floor/roof/people's pints etc. I had lots of fun and would certainly return for a few more games  and you can hire the ping pong table if you're in a group.

photos.caption: Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom

DyTAqo1pdrJYaBvLXDYeEw.text: THE GOOD:free wifiholes in the wallping pong tablecocktail listframed illustrations on display*amazing* sharing plattersTHE BAD:not being able to get a seat and order an *amazing* sharing platter after 7pm on a Friday nightTHE UGLY:my face (after hearing there is a £5 cover charge after 8pm on weekend nights)

3dkvBbj3pu6Aqu-G2ulOZw.text: Really cool day time to night time cafe come bar with a lot going on.  The Book Club hosts all kinds of fun nights and the occasional vintage clothing stalls on the weekends which are always a great place to get chatting to new people, maybe even make a few new pals! With ping pong tables - and a night dedicated to the game - speed dating, DJ nights and for the more crafty of you, screen printing for reasonable prices it's a great place to head to if you're looking for something a little different to do with your friends.   The decor is that of a cool New York loft space, with constantly changing art on the walls which is usually available for purchase. The staff are really friendly and all of the food and drinks are of high quality, all while not breaking the budget.

MRwkFwG0WCFNVXsEvP_hvQ.text: Went here for an informal business meeting and it was great! There was plenty of space to choose from on a Friday afternoon and my colleague and I chose a two-seater which had just enough room for our notebooks and plates. The place was quiet enough to have a good conversation and hear each other entirely and had other things going on that were entertaining to watch, such as two guys playing ping pong in the adjacent room.There is a combination of tables (small and bigger) and lounge spaces.You have to go up to the bar to order your food. We didn't know this at first and had to flag down a worker who told us.We ordered the beet falafel sandwich and orange juice. The sandwiches were much larger than I expected and were really good! I would order them again. The OJ is freshly squeezed.

vQZIxORwqEXS-NBGjfaNdQ.text: The Book Club is slowly becoming my go-to bar when I'm in and around the Shoreditch area. The best places to be seen and heard in change on almost a weekly basis in this area, but with the BC you have a really comfortable space to enjoy a few drinks. I've found it really suits every type of night, easily could enjoyably knock them back for that big night out, a lovely place for a quiet one on a Sunday and also an excellent spot for some drinks before running off for a nice meal. The bar is very well stocked, loads of options in the beer and cider departments and also some very good wines that compliment the food menu (which i'm yet to try, this will change soon). BC also have some excellent spirits, great gin is a highlight, and also a unique cocktail list. On my last visit I had a very cool twist on an old fashioned where tequila replaced the whiskey. Ok, it's something that would make Whiskey lovers revolt but as I love tequila and can't develop my taste buds enough to cope with whiskey, it was a pure delight. Fresh and also VERY more-ish. I'll let you decide if that's a good thing or not. (No, it is).BC put on a lot of cool events and there's a huge event space and extra bar downstairs that see a lot of gigs, talks and various other cool things to do. Can't remember who played but I went to a hip-hop night here a few months back and it was great, only a 5er to get in too! Other great things here include the staff, the decor and wait for it...THE PING PONG TABLE, YES! It does get busy as there's only one but beers and ping pong is up there with PB&J and Spaghetti and Meatballs. Great spot that I'd more than recommend checking out and if all else fails you can laugh at people bewilderment when they discover the Unisex toilets! BC, BC, BC!

GGCL1PlBg-j21xaP3_6taQ.text: Very nice atmosphere, slightly hipster - but in a good way! I was here for breakfast and got the bread with avocado and porched egg - very yum! Sadly they forgot the bacon we also order, which would have made it fantastic... I like the vibe and the prices are ok (£31 for 2 x breakfast, 2 x fresh pressed orange juice and 2 x coffees) Its worth a visit if you are in the area!

B_xyMhXPLwYJ0V5iFpvRwA.text: Great space to get some afternoon writing done while having a coffee or a beer, especially if you're someone who likes background noise, people coming and going, big picture windows to stare out... Lively and mostly full around lunchtime though I was able to find a seat easily. It calmed down nicely in the afternoon, enough for me to grab a comfy chair by the front window, order an IPA, and read a bit before calling it a day. Nice selection of beers, a very helpful (not to mention handsome) bartender, and spotless lavatories made this place a perfect choice for an afternoon of writing in London.

tqoFLW-mnZNxgh2AidGbag.text: (for the club night only)I had no idea what The Book Club was...I just tagged along with the birthday girl and friends on a busy Friday night.  I'm not sure if the scene and music changes much, but you're gonna get your 2000's R&B and hiphop, some Kanye & Drake, a dash of reggae, and a bit of 90's.  Scene? It's okay...excellent if you're still in Uni.  The older you get, the less tolerance you have for sweltering dancerooms and shoulder-to-shoulder crowds (or is it just me?).  I'd need to visit on its non-club days to get a wholesome gist of the venue.

QM42NuNDHZg6FcNZvvSIUw.text: Had brunch here. Order and pay at the back - the girl was a little snooty but the food was delicious - got the pancakes, and the pesto scrambled eggs with both the parma ham and salmon option. Very chilled and relaxed vibe - very hipster and shoreditch!

photos.caption: Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom

hDIf2NoNMHt222H2IGaIow.text: One of my favourite Shoreditch bars on the weekdays, The Book Club is worth checking out for some post-work drinks and nibbles as well, if you're feeling a bit peckish. The atmosphere is alternative, but there's no pretentious hipsters here. My favourite spot to have a catch up sesh with friends are the comfy couches and chairs right next to the door, and the ping pong table makes for a fun activity if you want to get on up and move around a bit. The cocktails are top-notch, and are pretty fairly priced compared to other bars in the area at about £8 each - my favourites are Honey Laundering and Don't go to Dalston.

WUOOV1yQ_syHeGgqgFr-kw.text: The Book Club exudes such a cool, lived in vibe in and is fairly easy to get to in Hoxton. The energy in here is great, it was fairly packed when we went on a Thursday night but we did manage to get a comfortable couch to hang out on.Definitely have some pretty creative cocktails and the food is great also. Highly recommend checking this place out!

IhdLtIVxFH34d_Lx4Las1Q.text: We stopped in here for a drink or two as our second stop on the Classy Cocktail Crawl. I was really disappointed. The venue was REALLY HOT, so we went outdoors and downstairs where there was a foosball table that gave you only seven balls if you put in a pound. And during which time some people (I assume who worked there), went into the closed downstairs bar, pulled the curtains and started blasting terrible music.And the drink wasn't very nice. And it took ages to get. Just wasn't really impressive overall really.

AnqDpHq1AXPtQ7LM0K2bGA.text: I've been here twice in the evening and both times were very enjoyable. They have some fun themed evenings that you should look out for. Arrive early to avoid paying a entrance fee.

OQBtggayi-oPfFcOZemN9g.text: This is a cool place to host parties, events and meetups. Have been to 3 so far. the free wifi is also a big plus as sometimes you can't get signal. Although, brace yourselves during winter as it's a bit of a walk from Old Street tube so make sure you get your coats on.

bInT6jE3A3w0tYB2jya3ig.text: Stopped here for breakfast and to get some work done. Before I sat down I asked the servers behind the bar if I should order at the counter or sit and they kindly said there was table service so I should just find a seat, which I did. I waited for about 25 minutes, was the only person there, and couldn't get the attention of a single person ... so I left.

YZ5hgM6kRy4Fdj1oPyxYuA.text: I love this place for a cocktail, some grub or even a cup of tea on your own accompanied by your laptop.Any time of the time there's something for you! I went with the girls this Sunday just gone for a good catch and the vibe & atmosphere was just great!

vupt-C-K7ZZoXzCTztiM2Q.text: When you're a sole traveler, you really appreciate a friendly bartender and I felt warmly welcomed by the bartender at The Book Club. I came here on a Thursday night and tried The Sweet as a Nut and the Long and Thin. Both were delicious drinks, but my weak US dollar couldn't handle anymore than two drinks and I had to leave. The Book Club seems like a really good place to meet and mingle with new people, and I actually did end up meeting a couple of interesting people and had some good quality conversation.Come here for the alcohol, stay for the people ;)

DXDZnZE6E9rP5tAdAtwG5w.text: I'd give this place zero stars if I could. The main problem with this place are the bouncers out the front. They are extremely rude to guests. Maybe they are intimidated by good looking girls I'm not sure but a place should be welcoming to guests not rude and obnoxious. The cocktails we tried were pretty ordinary and watered down and the crowd and music is awful. Do yourself a favour and go elsewhere!

Lbh4Yfk1-tjtU9m0yEqQ7g.text: The only thing missing here is a decent cup of tea or coffee! Atmosphere is great and the food and cocktails certainly look delicious. But the tea was so sad. Oh, and the wifi is more than a little spotty :(

0QH43CK92McOV5t4CJfdXw.text: What a great find! I went to The Book Club on a Sunday morning to catch up on some writing and fell in love with the place! Very spacious, great music, a laid-back environment and excellent food. I had the pancakes, which were delicious and then spent some quality time in a comfy chair by the window enjoying the atmosphere. The staff were also very polite and at no point did I feel like I had over stayed my welcome, even after being there for 3 hours. Highly recommended!

i-kgNvpTSuicVG-6EQ6Dzg.text: The Book Club is an excellent all rounder of a venue. It's great for breakfast, lunch or dinner. Food is great, from soups, to full on burgers. Orange juice of course is freshly squeezed with one of those machines that you can see do all the squeezing! Essentially if The Book Club is going to do something. It seems the mission is to do it well.The venue itself has a small room for table tennis. A place for hats and jackets. A small space in the basement for a bar and live music. Free Wifi, comfy sofas.Not content with all that which would be a selling point itself in any normal Shoreditch haunt, I haven't begun to mention the many multitude of events that are going on all the time. Almost every  single day of the week? Ping pong competitions, life drawing, Yoga, Arts/Crafts, Film nights, theme nights?. This place is Intimate, friendly, functional and trendy without bordering on the pretentious.It's a jack of all trades, and proud of it.

9ulucNZCEL3J2g4HQxJVFQ.text: I've been to some really nice spots in London, but was lookin for a chill location to continue writing and hopefully finish my book.  I found out about The Book Club by doing a Google search for "great places to write in London".  Boy was this recommendation accurate!  It was a little difficult to find walking from the Liverpool Street tube station, but well worth the hassle.  It's officially one of my favorite spots in London.  I hate to write that because what I like about it would be ruined if you had to queue up outside.The interior is full of natural light from the giant picture windows that look out into a nondescript little alley.  The alley sounds horrible, but there is some art grafitti on the brick wall across the way and people constantly passing outside.  Inside, the walls are brick, painted white and bright with black words in cursive to add interest.  There are also books hanging on the wall and some really phenomenal art pieces, plus modern folk style green plants in terra-cotta pots on the wall.  The internal ambiance is amplified by the choice of indie rock and old school r&b and pop tunes (think Michael Jackson in his younger days).  I should probably add that I was the only one working who had a PC instead of a MAC, and that the choice of male attire was the modern pantaloon a.k.a. skinny jeans.  I didnt mind either way.  The MAC is on my dream list and the pants increased my viewing pleasure.  As for the food, well, it's organic, with some choice vegetarian items, but of course I had ham, free-range eggs, and chips (french fries).  My meal was delicious!  And to top it off they have a full bar and coffee bar.  Its like mom's modern farm kitchen if it had a bar and coffee shop.  Good grief, I've become effusive!  I can't say enough good things here.  I will be back, maybe daily, while I'm in London this month.  In a place like this I'm actually inspired that my labor will yield fruit.  Dallas, are you paying attention?  You need a place like this.

ZDV_1_0rkLX-JmwLdhZMIw.text: A good spot for morning coworking, coffee, and breakfast.The space is open and well lit, with tons of rotating art. It's good for creativity and just staring off blankly into the distance.If you come in the morning though, you'll probably want to leave by lunch when all the tables fill up and you start getting looks at your empty space with two finished coffee mugs. They also reserve out tables in the afternoon and evening for reservations and events, so the freely available tables decrease as the day goes on.

wNNvrz6fRzXmSa70xMb-Dw.text: The venue is cute and I liked the overall vibes of the place, but my friend and I came here for Pancake Day to get their limited edition Espresso Martini Pancakes. The pancakes looked nowhere near as beautiful as the ones they posted on Facebook, and they tasted soo bland. Was not a huge fan.

photos.caption: Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom

vUaSaRmVlDAvZ0rr6S3_CA.text: For breakfast, this place isn't great. The avo toast with salmon looks good but it just eh. Kinda soggy. Service sucks and is disorganized.  Wouldn't come back for breakfast.

ZHKkebxYylxkJS-97IeZ7g.text: Super chill spot! Loved the ping pong table in the back, the crowd was fun & the drinks ---so good! They have one of their speciality drinks (includes tequila) forgot the name, it's on their chalkboard, just ask :) if you're a tourist or a local, perfect place to lounge.

Y4zTUfTwVPAgMIl0wYNB8g.text: We came here with the intention to check out the current curation of screen prints made by a friend. We met in the afternoon and the place was nicely busy with various groups of happy people. The space is open and there was plenty of seating in small tables and on the large mess hall type benches near the bar and kitchen. I liked the large windows at the from of the place and the fact they had a ping pong table in the corner.The staff were casual and friendly. We loved it here so much we stayed on for lunch. We got two beef brisket burgers with additional cheese and bacon, which were served with crispy onion rings, and a steak sandwich which was swerved with chips. Both choices were really tasty and cane promptly.I'd definitely recommend you come here by yourself to study/work, on a date or in a group as there seemed to be all these types of groups enjoying themselves in the relaxed atmosphere. I hear they also do club nights and all sorts of arty things here too!

photos.caption: Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom. Beef brisket burger
Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom. Steak sandwich
Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom

Ir0pCuq5RYqQgX7o6fzEiA.text: Cafe vibe by day, bar party vibes in evening. Food is so-so, venue itself is pretty good, 2 floors and space for a ping pong table.

photos.caption: Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom

UG3y-_bx_wYiPPMGXkjXmQ.text: We were looking for a spot to grab brunch. One spot kept coming up, the Book Club. Needless to say it was a welcome surprise to find some pretty tasty bites in a restaurant/art gallery/co-working space. Needless to say, they served up some pretty impressive bites in a very cool and different space.Let me start off with the space. It is simple. Open. Comfortable. It offers a good variety of space for both small groups and large parties. It is bright and showcases a rotating series of art that liven up the space and make it rather relatable. The menu is straight forward. It isn't complex and it doesn't try to be something it is not. The eggs benedict was pretty respectable with a very well prepared poached eggs topping some ham and an english muffin. The hollandaise was well done and not too heavy and the basil and pepper finishing off the flavors and brought balance. Americans beware, bacon in the UK is not bacon in the US.Definitely check it out if you are in the neighborhood. It is offering a pretty respectable breakfast (and morning cocktails) in a very awesome area of town that is showing London can be different.

FTmP0wRQSra8Vw-dmzmShQ.text: If you love mediocre drinks, door staff drunk on power, and consistently disappointing experiences, the Book Club is the place for you!Pros: Lightbulb ceilingCons: Everything else--they don't even have books, lying bastards

RylsjwFgqJ1NUqFD_-9vXg.text: For all the wonderful touting of this bar and all of its novelty! I was so pumped to drop in on the perfect day.The acoustics were amazingly bad. I had to leave. No fun.

NDBAepZxWwLjtVvTZwyARA.text: So I'd heard really great things about the Book Club, everyone reckons it's a good place for drinks and chilling out with your mates. However, when I came here it wasn't quite what I was expecting. The upstairs bar is quite small and the toilets were a little on the rough side. I didn't venture downstairs, but maybe that's where the fun is. Upstairs is light but the table was sat at was too small for the chairs and the music was too loud, it was hard to hear what people were saying. For a place which is supposed to be chilled out and social, I didn't feel like it lived up to either description. Am I missing something here?

azzUl9t12k5K2SwpZn8pcw.text: One of my favourite places to spend time procrastinating and sometimes even working. What's great: Good vibes, free Wifi attracting workaholics and hypster kids.What's not: It gets busy at night, especially when there's some event and you could dry out waiting for drinks. By DayIdeal for getting some drinks, making photos of lattes and chilling. The coffee bar and the morning menu make me feel like at mom's house - if she had a bar. The burgers are good, not the best I've tried, but still pretty good. I've been willing to try their freshly made cakes for a long time. You can even play ping pong if you feel like moving and sweating, which is not my favourite thing, but it's still very cool for a cafe. By NightWhen the sun goes down, a crowd of  aggressive party people appears out of nowhere and the place gets so crowded, you'll sweat your ass off. There's a program of events like live art, music and films. They encourage creative and talented people to share their skills which is the main reason I like this place so much.On weekends, the place becomes more of a nightclub, with local and national DJs. What to expect: Great music, party girls and drunk guys.Also:  Drunk boyfriends may appear, be aware!

photos.caption: Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom

g3oaECrVBenjprRXYRTO8g.text: Nice big open space! Great for working during the day. I arrived late afternoon but I've heard it's a great nighttime location too! I had a hot chocolate later followed by The Cajun wedges from the light bites section on the menus. The wedges were impressive in both size and flavour! They have a table tennis table in the main cafe and also foosball in the lounge downstairs! I'll definitely be back to try one of their cocktails - the bartender was writing up today's selection as we left!

photos.caption: Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom. Larger than life Cajun Wedges!
Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom. Nice open space for working/relaxing/catching up with friends
Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom. Hot chocolate! Good size and really chocolatey!

iZOViT-2N9XTTnzBbtRARQ.text: Went there to get some work done on my laptop, around 3pm. Great place, lots of space, friendly people, good atmosphere. Good wifi, and I also saw some other people working there. Had a cappuccino to start with and felt a bit hungry so I decided to try the burger with fries. Both good, but fries weren't hand cut and the burger was a bit 'simple'. Meat was perfect, tasty and juicy though. Also great, they have tab water with cucumber, really refreshing. Seems to be a great place for cocktails too as I saw them put a lot of effort into them. Also a great place to get yourself distracted for a while playing table tennis with friends. I'll definitely be back, also to check out what the place looks like in the evenings, looks like a great place to have some wine and a dance with some friends.

photos.caption: Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom. View outside the window front.
Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom. Bartender writing down the Cocktails for the night.

pG_aZWmekDfZolaqjswmxw.text: Came here late night. Hipster Vibe. I really like the atmosphere of this place. Unfortunately I did not stay here to long because my mate got sick (threw up in the middle of place). The main floor wasn't packed but just enough space. I didn't get to venture to the other floors. I would come back here, but my mates don't car for it. Single bathrooms, so there is always a queue.

o9Jr15naSE44yLoPyW2UgA.text: Oh what a wonderful spot tucked away in the middle of shoreditch -fun at night and perfect for working during the day

343tvaAycnum2jg9ZRHKsA.text: I went to this place for there mere reason that I wanted to get off the tourist path and downtown strips and see a local neighborhood of London.  I loved this place !! The accents, the local flavor (very hipster), and the food presentation - very delicious ! Totally recommend this place to any tourist who wants to visit deep into London

BkfZJDm0kzCqXJo0mhh_9A.text: Lovely decorated place. Nice location. Good for hang out or spending a day doing projects. Is my first time here I didn't know we have to order at the till and for The staff were unfriendly which was a total turn off. I have more to say but is just pointless

photos.caption: Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom. Interior of the book club

7kMnZMutfPusbdDEiUnmSg.text: Review for the brunch (this place is also a bar / club at night) - great place for brunch! You have to go order and pay at the bar so don't wait for the waiter to come get your order. Nice atmosphere and great food. I had the avocado on toast with poached eggs and smoked salmon and loved it.

photos.caption: Photo of The Book Club - London, United Kingdom. Avocado on toast with poached eggs and smoked salmon, one of the best versions of this brunch classic that I have had!

g3FwOkcsdnr1GsLC3p-sJw.text: I had the pleasure of trying out the book club earlier today and it was outstanding. Friendly decor, bright, good for groups and the flat white ... Wow ... And if you read any of my past reviews I'm very picky with my flat white. :)I didn't have the pleasure sadly to sample the good offering but the meals my friends ordered were huge and looked and smelled amazing ... Especially the pancake with bacon!The only negative comment came from my Canadian friend who noticed they only have "maple flavoured syrup" instead of actually maple syrup ... So if your Canadian this might not become your usual brunch spot! :)

ETJLQQGoVqj8pe7xpVN4xQ.text: urban canteen style. bar is good, great for working and outing. ping pong table is fun for group.

V06gFB73WDKicAI2NHbaYA.text: Having missed Home (the previous occupants of 110 Leonard Street) I though I'd check this jaunt out.The interior looks like a relaxed Scandinavian living room, with wooden chairs and benches as well as loungy sofas for actual reading.The staff are friendly and the food is well portioned and wholesome without a big price tag.There's the opportunity to play Ping Pong on the ground floor or pool in the basement, where the DJ and dance floor is.The Book Club also offer talks, reading and dancing workshops, just look out for their flyers.A nice place to hang out of an evening.

jm9-Oc4LBHeRA515130chA.text: Really cool place, good music and quality sharing food (nachos are a winner)! Only let down were the jugs of cocktails which entice you in with great names that arnt backed up by the taste. Stick to the beers and you'll have a great night.

hxPM8eegFz-JbzYOJSw0EQ.text: We went to the Book Club on Saturday night. There was about a 20 minute wait to get in, which is fine really, but it was extremely hot inside and it was packed to the rafters with painfully cool hipsters (to be expected in the area). Entry was £5 and drinks weren't too badly priced. The decor is pretty nice, I like the open plan of the upstairs room and the light-bulbed ceiling downstairs is striking. They had an amazing band playing downstairs as well, we were twisting the night away to the rockabilly tunes (I have no idea if those two things are from the same era). Overall, a fun, reasonably priced place that I would to go to for a dance rather than to try to chat with friends.

Lxv1U-YnEk5heDJaYGSYuQ.text: The sort of place where idiot bouncers make you queue unnecessarily in order to make the club seem popular. The bouncers in question are the worst kind too, who seem to think they are working outside the Palais in Essex circa 1992.Forget the ping pong, there is one table and you won't get a game. The food is poor, drinks ove- priced and the music sh*te.Decor is quite cool though.

fghUGyHoRGqoRFnzz79kiA.text: pretty cool bar in east london, haven't experience the food or daytime feel of it but at night it was lively with a good mix of 20s crowd. drinks seem reasonably priced and the place wasn't TOO packed so still had some breathing room to manuever in a group and make your way to the bar.

PpCxsdjJIwFoJwhHsk7Q-A.text: Great place to go for after work drinks. Spacious with plenty of places to sit so if you get down there early you should be set for the night - you might even get to the table tennis table if your lucky!

KuAO9g9tqldjvnkJnH4i6Q.text: Cracking venue, shame about the door staff! Um, no seriously...this is one of the most versatile bar/clubs in the triangle populated by the usual spread of Ditchside riff raff and actually last night, an onslaught of lesbians for the party of the year *holler* for themostcake.co.uk, the second such event held here. Kitchen canteen-y upstairs, light bulb ceiling downstairs, this venue compels me to whip out the disco stick and leaves me begging for more and more. Check out themostcake.co.uk for a fuller exposé on the event.

erCSLYhoj5s__gnfZcb17Q.text: Don't know about evenings here, but brunch was spot on - good prices, not crowded at all, and tables are spaced out so you're not overhearing a dozen other conversations. Looked like there was a good ping pong game going on around the corner from the dining area as well. Bar staff were lovely and friendly and food was great (did I mention french toast is only 3.50?!)

UFuwJOFtfgesJ2Oo22ZIDg.text: So much better than when it was Home.

feAscU4jvg40vePYnGUmKA.text: brilliant - the ping pong was free (the elbow rooms should learn from this!!) and the food was good though the service wasn't top notch, still it's a lovely vibe, relaxed with some fabulous photography on the walls. Recommend you check it out!

3RmIlbdpjTd0Om9qzy9Xfw.text: Decent bar with some nice quiet spots and a dance floor downstairs. The dishes of food eaten by customers in the evening however always seem to be on the tables until midnight just festering. Interesting decor, done on the cheap like shabby chic style and then with standard trendy prices. Prices weren't on the whole too high to be fair. A fiver get in though. It's nice that there is a ping pong table and pool table. Gives you something to do if you're not getting completely pissed silly. The bouncers were alright but racial profiling. Concerned about Algerians one told me in a jovial tone.

H83M5Ht0K9_7IjJx0-Kt_A.text: The Book Club is open from early morning for breakfast then in the afternoon there's Afternoon Tea; with champagne if you want it. Weekends get busy! If it's a bank holiday or special event there might also be a street festival all the way up Leonard Street which is organised by The Book Club. At quiet times you can pull out a board game and relax.
